importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, marks the fatal incident involving Brett James, a prominent songwriter, and is central to understanding the timeline and context of the accident.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame of the incident (the exact day of the crash) is critical for aviation safety investigations and helps establish when and how the sequence of events unfolded.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for his collaborations with major artists like Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during its flight, leading to a fatal crash.

James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, and although air traffic control approved it, he failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency, which may have contributed to miscommunication.
The plane, a Cirrus SR22T, flew over the runway, executed a left turn, and then descended into a spiral before crashing.
The NTSB investigation found no mechanical issues with the aircraft, indicating the accident was likely due to pilot error or communication failure.

James co-wrote the song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood in 2005, which marked a major breakthrough in his career and established him as one of country music’s most sought-after songwriters.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to tune to CTAF, which is a critical safety protocol, and this error likely contributed to the communication breakdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Grammy-winning songwriter and music industry collaborator, Brett James, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the Cirrus SR22T aircraft he was piloting entered a 'tightening spiral' during a flight that included a planned visual approach to runway 7. James had failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), leading to a loss of communication with air traffic control, and the plane descended into a spiral before crashing. No mechanical issues were found in the aircraft. The incident highlights a critical aviation safety issue related to pilot communication protocols and the risks associated with miscommunication in visual approaches.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, NTSB says
